Expectation1: Teaching children moral values and discipline
Situation1: At home, the child is learning daily manners, and the parent should provide guidance
Situation2: They notice dust and mess building up and carry out more regular cleaning tasks.
Story: I was in the living room, watching my daughter fidget with her toys, crumbs scattered around her feet. As a parent, I knew this was the perfect moment to teach her about cleaning up after herself, about responsibility and respect for our home. I wanted to sit beside her, gently guide her to pick up the crumbs, explain why it mattered, and praise her for every small effort. But as a housekeeping cleaner, I saw the dust gathering on the shelves, the streaks on the windows, and the sticky fingerprints on the table. My supervisor’s words echoed in my mind: “Every corner spotless, every surface shining.” I felt the pressure to grab my cleaning supplies and tackle the mess myself, to meet the high standards expected of me. My heart tugged in two directions—one part urging me to slow down and teach, the other pushing me to clean quickly and thoroughly. I stood there, torn, the vacuum in one hand and my daughter’s hopeful eyes on me, unsure which role to answer first.
